overview.title: Overview
bullets: Bollinger Bands are a popular technical analysis tool used to measure market volatility and identify overbought or oversold conditions.
The indicator comprises three lines: a middle band (typically a 20-period moving average) and upper/lower bands set a number of standard deviations from the middle.
They help traders anticipate potential price moves by examining the relationship between price and volatility.

items.title: Middle Band
items.desc: A moving average (usually 20 periods) that smooths price data and helps identify the prevailing trend.

items.title: Upper Band
items.desc: Typically set 2 standard deviations above the middle band; price reaching it may indicate potential overbought conditions.

items.title: Lower Band
items.desc: Typically set 2 standard deviations below the middle band; price approaching it may indicate potential oversold conditions.

items.title: Volatility Interpretation
items.desc: Bands widen during high volatility and contract during low volatility, which can precede trend changes or breakouts.

items.title: 1. Bollinger Band Squeeze
points: Formation: Bands contract, indicating low volatility that may precede a significant move.
Interpretation: Breakout above the upper band suggests bullish continuation; breakdown below the lower band suggests bearish continuation.
Confirmation: Use volume or complementary indicators to validate breakout direction.

items.title: 2. Overbought & Oversold Reversals
points: Overbought: Price touching or moving outside the upper band may precede a downward reversal.
Oversold: Price touching or moving outside the lower band may precede an upward reversal.
Use Confirmation: RSI or similar oscillators can improve reliability.

items.title: 3. Riding the Bands (Trend Following)
points: Trend Signal: Price hugging the upper band indicates a strong uptrend; hugging the lower band indicates a strong downtrend.
Entry/Exit: Trade in the trend direction, using the middle band as a trailing stop or dynamic exit.

limitations.title: Limitations
bullets: Lagging Indicator: Derived from historical prices, so it may react slowly to abrupt market changes.
False Signals: In choppy markets, bands can generate misleading overbought/oversold signals.
